natural problem: Nine stones are arranged in a straight line. They are counted from  left to right as $1,2,3, \ldots, 9$, and then from right to left, so that the stone previously counted as 8 is counted as 10. The pattern is continued to the left until the stone previously counted as 1 is counted as 17. The pattern then reverses so that the stone originally counted as 2 is counted as 18, 3 as 19, and so on. The counting continues in this manner. Which of the original stones is counted as 99? Express your answer as a single digit which corresponds to the first digit assigned to that stone.
natural solution: First we note that 16 stones are enumerated before the pattern repeats.

Therefore, if the count enumerates a stone as $n$, then that stone is enumerated $k$ for every  \[k\equiv n\pmod{16}\] (though all but the end stones are represented by two residue classes in this way).
Since $99\equiv3\pmod{16}$, stone number $\boxed{3}$ is counted as 99.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. (n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 9) \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. (n > 9 \<and> n \<le> 17) \<longrightarrow> f n = 18 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. (n > 17 \<and> n \<le> 25) \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 8"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. (n > 25) \<longrightarrow> f n = f (n - 16)"
shows  "f 99 = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine stones are arranged in a straight line. They are counted from  left to right as $1,2,3, \ldots, 9$, and then from right to left, so that the stone previously counted as 8 is counted as 10. The pattern is continued to the left until the stone previously counted as 1 is counted as 17. The pattern then reverses so that the stone originally counted as 2 is counted as 18, 3 as 19, and so on. The counting continues in this manner. Which of the original stones is counted as 99? Express your answer as a single digit which corresponds to the first digit assigned to that stone. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First we note that 16 stones are enumerated before the pattern repeats.
 Therefore, if the count enumerates a stone as $n$, then that stone is enumerated $k$ for every  \[k\equiv n\pmod{16}\] (though all but the end stones are represented by two residue classes in this way).
 Since $99\equiv3\pmod{16}$, stone number $\boxed{3}$ is counted as 99.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. (n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 9) \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. (n > 9 \<and> n \<le> 17) \<longrightarrow> f n = 18 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. (n > 17 \<and> n \<le> 25) \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 8"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. (n > 25) \<longrightarrow> f n = f (n - 16)"
shows  "f 99 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined for all positive integers $n$. If $1 \leq n \leq 9$, then $f(n) = n$. If $9 < n \leq 17$, then $f(n) = 18 - n$. If $17 < n \leq 25$, then $f(n) = n - 8$. And if $n > 25$, then $f(n) = f(n - 16)$. What is the value of $f(99)$? The final answer is $3$.

fixes n :: nat

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n mod 16 = 0 \<longrightarrow> n div 16 mod 9 = 0"
and h1 : "n mod 16 \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> n div 16 mod 9 = 8 - (n mod 16 - 1) mod 9"
and h2 : "n = 99"
shows  "n div 16 mod 9 + 1 = 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine stones are arranged in a straight line. They are counted from  left to right as $1,2,3, \ldots, 9$, and then from right to left, so that the stone previously counted as 8 is counted as 10. The pattern is continued to the left until the stone previously counted as 1 is counted as 17. The pattern then reverses so that the stone originally counted as 2 is counted as 18, 3 as 19, and so on. The counting continues in this manner. Which of the original stones is counted as 99? Express your answer as a single digit which corresponds to the first digit assigned to that stone. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First we note that 16 stones are enumerated before the pattern repeats.
 Therefore, if the count enumerates a stone as $n$, then that stone is enumerated $k$ for every  \[k\equiv n\pmod{16}\] (though all but the end stones are represented by two residue classes in this way).
 Since $99\equiv3\pmod{16}$, stone number $\boxed{3}$ is counted as 99.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n mod 16 = 0 \<longrightarrow> n div 16 mod 9 = 0"
and h1 : "n mod 16 \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> n div 16 mod 9 = 8 - (n mod 16 - 1) mod 9"
and h2 : "n = 99"
shows  "n div 16 mod 9 + 1 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If $n$ is a natural number such that $n$ divided by $16$ leaves a remainder of $0$, then $n$ divided by $16$, then divided by $9$ leaves a remainder of $0$. If $n$ divided by $16$ leaves a remainder not equal to $0$, then $n$ divided by $16$, then divided by $9$ leaves a remainder of $8 - ((n$ remainder $16) - 1)$ remainder $9$. Given $n = 99$, find the value of $n$ divided by $16$, then divided by $9$, plus $1$. The final answer is $3$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and stone :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "stone 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. (n > 0 \<and> n \<le> 9) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone n + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. (n > 9 \<and> n \<le> 17) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone (17 - (n - 9))"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. (n > 17 \<and> n mod 16 \<noteq> 0) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone ((n mod 16) + 1)"
and h4 : "\<forall>n. (n > 17 \<and> n mod 16 = 0) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone 1"
shows  "stone 99 = 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine stones are arranged in a straight line. They are counted from  left to right as $1,2,3, \ldots, 9$, and then from right to left, so that the stone previously counted as 8 is counted as 10. The pattern is continued to the left until the stone previously counted as 1 is counted as 17. The pattern then reverses so that the stone originally counted as 2 is counted as 18, 3 as 19, and so on. The counting continues in this manner. Which of the original stones is counted as 99? Express your answer as a single digit which corresponds to the first digit assigned to that stone. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First we note that 16 stones are enumerated before the pattern repeats.
 Therefore, if the count enumerates a stone as $n$, then that stone is enumerated $k$ for every  \[k\equiv n\pmod{16}\] (though all but the end stones are represented by two residue classes in this way).
 Since $99\equiv3\pmod{16}$, stone number $\boxed{3}$ is counted as 99.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and stone :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "stone 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. (n > 0 \<and> n \<le> 9) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone n + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. (n > 9 \<and> n \<le> 17) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone (17 - (n - 9))"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. (n > 17 \<and> n mod 16 \<noteq> 0) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone ((n mod 16) + 1)"
and h4 : "\<forall>n. (n > 17 \<and> n mod 16 = 0) \<longrightarrow> stone (n + 1) = stone 1"
shows  "stone 99 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
There is a pile of stones, and the stones are removed according to the following rules:

- The first stone is removed.
- For the next 9 stones (up to the 10th), one stone is removed at a time.
- For the following stones from the 11th to the 17th, the number of stones removed follows a pattern that is symmetric to the pattern from the 2nd to the 9th stone.
- For stones beyond the 17th, the pattern of removal repeats every 16 stones. If the stone number is not a multiple of 16, the number of stones removed is the same as for the stone in the position of the remainder of the division of the stone number by 16 plus 1. If the stone number is a multiple of 16, the number of stones removed is the same as for the first stone.

What is the number of stones removed when the 99th stone is reached? The final answer is 3.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes count :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> count n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 17 \<longrightarrow> count n = 18 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 18 \<and> n \<le> 25 \<longrightarrow> count n = n - 8"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 26 \<and> n \<le> 33 \<longrightarrow> count n = 34 - n"
and h4 : "count 99 = 3"
shows  "count 99 = 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine stones are arranged in a straight line. They are counted from  left to right as $1,2,3, \ldots, 9$, and then from right to left, so that the stone previously counted as 8 is counted as 10. The pattern is continued to the left until the stone previously counted as 1 is counted as 17. The pattern then reverses so that the stone originally counted as 2 is counted as 18, 3 as 19, and so on. The counting continues in this manner. Which of the original stones is counted as 99? Express your answer as a single digit which corresponds to the first digit assigned to that stone. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First we note that 16 stones are enumerated before the pattern repeats.
 Therefore, if the count enumerates a stone as $n$, then that stone is enumerated $k$ for every  \[k\equiv n\pmod{16}\] (though all but the end stones are represented by two residue classes in this way).
 Since $99\equiv3\pmod{16}$, stone number $\boxed{3}$ is counted as 99.
 *)

theorem 
fixes count :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> count n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 17 \<longrightarrow> count n = 18 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 18 \<and> n \<le> 25 \<longrightarrow> count n = n - 8"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 26 \<and> n \<le> 33 \<longrightarrow> count n = 34 - n"
and h4 : "count 99 = 3"
shows  "count 99 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Define a function 'count' on the integers as follows: For numbers between 1 and 9 (inclusive), the function returns the number itself. For numbers between 10 and 17 (inclusive), the function returns the result of subtracting the number from 18. For numbers between 18 and 25 (inclusive), the function returns the result of subtracting 8 from the number. For numbers between 26 and 33 (inclusive), the function returns the result of subtracting the number from 34. Lastly, the function returns 3 for the number 99. What is the function value at 99? The final answer is 3.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 17 \<longrightarrow> f n = 18 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. 18 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 25 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 8"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. 26 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 33 \<longrightarrow> f n = 34 - n"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. 34 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 41 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 16"
and h5 : "\<forall> n. 42 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 49 \<longrightarrow> f n = 50 - n"
and h6 : "\<forall> n. 50 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 57 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 24"
and h7 : "\<forall> n. 58 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 65 \<longrightarrow> f n = 66 - n"
and h8 : "\<forall> n. 66 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 73 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 32"
and h9 : "\<forall> n. 74 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 81 \<longrightarrow> f n = 82 - n"
and h10 : "\<forall> n. 82 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 89 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 40"
and h11 : "\<forall> n. 90 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 97 \<longrightarrow> f n = 98 - n"
and h12 : "\<forall> n. 98 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 105 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 48"
shows  "f 99 = 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine stones are arranged in a straight line. They are counted from  left to right as $1,2,3, \ldots, 9$, and then from right to left, so that the stone previously counted as 8 is counted as 10. The pattern is continued to the left until the stone previously counted as 1 is counted as 17. The pattern then reverses so that the stone originally counted as 2 is counted as 18, 3 as 19, and so on. The counting continues in this manner. Which of the original stones is counted as 99? Express your answer as a single digit which corresponds to the first digit assigned to that stone. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First we note that 16 stones are enumerated before the pattern repeats.
 Therefore, if the count enumerates a stone as $n$, then that stone is enumerated $k$ for every  \[k\equiv n\pmod{16}\] (though all but the end stones are represented by two residue classes in this way).
 Since $99\equiv3\pmod{16}$, stone number $\boxed{3}$ is counted as 99.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 17 \<longrightarrow> f n = 18 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. 18 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 25 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 8"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. 26 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 33 \<longrightarrow> f n = 34 - n"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. 34 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 41 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 16"
and h5 : "\<forall> n. 42 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 49 \<longrightarrow> f n = 50 - n"
and h6 : "\<forall> n. 50 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 57 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 24"
and h7 : "\<forall> n. 58 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 65 \<longrightarrow> f n = 66 - n"
and h8 : "\<forall> n. 66 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 73 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 32"
and h9 : "\<forall> n. 74 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 81 \<longrightarrow> f n = 82 - n"
and h10 : "\<forall> n. 82 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 89 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 40"
and h11 : "\<forall> n. 90 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 97 \<longrightarrow> f n = 98 - n"
and h12 : "\<forall> n. 98 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 105 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 48"
shows  "f 99 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined on the integers as follows: for $1 \leq n \leq 9$, $f(n) = n$; for $10 \leq n \leq 17$, $f(n) = 18 - n$; for $18 \leq n \leq 25$, $f(n) = n - 8$; for $26 \leq n \leq 33$, $f(n) = 34 - n$; for $34 \leq n \leq 41$, $f(n) = n - 16$; for $42 \leq n \leq 49$, $f(n) = 50 - n$; for $50 \leq n \leq 57$, $f(n) = n - 24$; for $58 \leq n \leq 65$, $f(n) = 66 - n$; for $66 \leq n \leq 73$, $f(n) = n - 32$; for $74 \leq n \leq 81$, $f(n) = 82 - n$; for $82 \leq n \leq 89$, $f(n) = n - 40$; for $90 \leq n \leq 97$, $f(n) = 98 - n$; for $98 \leq n \leq 105$, $f(n) = n - 48$. What is $f(99)$? The final answer is $3$.
